name: acetamide, n-(5-nitro-2-propoxyphenyl)-
Reason: The molecule 'acetamide, n-(5-nitro-2-propoxyphenyl)-' can be broken down into several functional groups and structural features that influence its melting point. Firstly, the basic phenyl ring structure has a melting point influence that can be approximated based on benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. Various substituents will alter this base value. The nitro group is an electron-withdrawing group that generally increases the melting point due to intermolecular interactions like hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole attractions; we could estimate its contribution to be around +80°C. On the other hand, the propoxy group is an alkoxy group (an ether) that is generally a bulky substituent, which might lower the melting point compared to a directly connected group due to less effective packing; its effect could be estimated at -20°C. The acetamide portion contains both a carbonyl and an amide linkage. The amide is capable of hydrogen bonding, which usually raises the melting point significantly; this could be approximated as a +60°C increase. Combining these estimations: Base phenol ring: 5.5; Nitro group: +80; Propoxy group: -20; Acetamide: +60.

name: acetamide, n-(5-nitro-2-propoxyphenyl)-

Adding these together: Benzene base: 5.5°C; Nitro group: +80°C; Propoxy group: -20°C; Acetamide: +60°C gives the estimated melting point.
